image.altText: Half underwater half sunset

items.synopsis: Climate scientists say natural "anaesthetics" have been masking the true impact of climate change for years but have now worn off. Here's why the world's ocean temperatures are at record highs and what they could bring.

title.children: With the world's oceans in the middle of an unprecedented heatwave, scientists are worried

image.altText: A photo of a car and a trailer attached to it which has completely collapsed

items.synopsis: A Victorian man recalls the terrifying moment his camper trailer was stolen while he and his partner were sleeping inside on the Great Ocean Road at the weekend.

title.children: Couple have four-wheel drive and camper trailer stolen while sleeping inside

image.altText: A man sitting on a bench looks ahead at the sunset with a neutral expression. He's wearing an Australian Rules jersey.

items.synopsis: No professional male AFL player, past or present, has ever publicly come out as gay or bisexual. Insiders say a culture of homophobia lingers.

title.children: Michael's an out gay man who plays Aussie rules. Why isn't there anyone like him in the AFL?

image.altText: A man in a dark shirt in an office

items.synopsis: A former executive at one of the country's most disastrous share market floats in years says he wasn't surprised when the share price crashed, wiping billions of dollars from the fortunes of investors, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: 'Stuck with the rancid bacon': Insider lifts lid on the share market disaster that cost investors billions

image.altText: Olga Carmona smiles with her World Cup winner's medal around her neck

items.synopsis: Just hours after a player-of-the-match performance in the Women's World Cup final, Spain captain Olga Carmona found out her father had died.

title.children: Spain World Cup hero Olga Carmona learns of father's death after final victory

image.altText: Kate Hore hugs Melbourne Demons teammates and shouts after winning the AFL Women's grand final.

items.synopsis: The AFL boosts player prize money in the women's competition by almost 100 per cent to be equal with the men, but the pool will be split across eight women's teams as opposed to four men's teams.

title.children: AFLW player prize money jumps to $1.1 million to match men's competition, but split over twice as many teams

image.altText: A team of soccer players wearing red and blue celebrates after winning a competition

items.synopsis: While they made history on Sunday night, Spain's first Women's World Cup title will always be haunted by the players who weren't there.

title.children: Spain's World Cup win lays bare the progress and problems of women's football

image.altText: Tameka Yallop (blurry in the foreground) carries her daughter as she waves to an applauding crowd at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: It's normal to feel some symptoms of football withdrawal after the Matildas' run and the joy of the Women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand. So, here's how to keep riding that train.

title.children: How to keep getting your Matildas fix after the Women's World Cup

image.altText: A person on a dirt bike in the bush.

items.synopsis: Illegal dirt bike riders are creating an environmental disaster for some of the Victoria's most delicate vegetation, conservation regulator says

title.children: Dirt bike riders being criticised for illegal tracks in Victoria's Otways region, but they say it's their only safe option

image.altText: Damien Hardwick stands holding a footy while wearing a Gold Coast Suns polo

items.synopsis: Damien Hardwick signs a six-year deal to coach the Gold Coast Suns months after stepping away from Richmond, where he led the Tigers to three premierships.

title.children: Suns complete Hardwick coup as triple-premiership coach joins Gold Coast

image.altText: An AFP sign above a front door

items.synopsis: The court was asked to adjourn the case of a man facing 1,623 child sex abuse charges until next year due to the "voluminous" nature of the material.

title.children: 'Need more time': Court denies 2024 adjournment request for man facing more than 1,600 child sex offences

image.altText: ses workers lower themselves into a sinkhole

items.synopsis: After prolonged wet weather, sinkholes are appearing in Ballarat. And with no good mining records from the historic 1850s gold rush, there's no way of knowing where the next one will open up.

title.children: Could you have an old gold mine under your backyard? In this regional city, it's possible

image.altText: A group of teenage girl cricketers take to the field. They are wearing green shirts. They look proud and fierce.

items.synopsis: When Abby was growing up there was no girls' cricket team, so she and her mum started their own. Now the league has grown, and local girls are getting noticed by state selectors.

title.children: There was no girls cricket team in her hometown, so Abby and her mum started a league of their own

image.altText: Tayla Cox wears pink and holds her baby girl Murphy

items.synopsis: The bodies of Tayla Black and her daughter, Murphy Margaret were found by police in their Rockhampton home two weeks ago. Ms Black’s husband, Matthew Cox was charged with their murders.

title.children: 'A tragedy for everyone': Man accused of murdering his wife and 11-week-old baby faces court

image.altText: Woman with blonde hair wearing a burnt orange top with black spots, holding a wine glass containing honey.

items.synopsis: Dusty, fruity, floral and woody are just some of the words honey sommelier Jessica Locarnini uses to describe Australia's vast range of honey flavours. She's on a mission to teach people across the country about the unique characteristics of honey.

title.children: How do you describe the taste of honey? Australia's only honey sommelier says it's not just 'sweet'

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas speaks to the media.

items.synopsis: The families of more than 200 children caught up in Adelaide's Women's and Children's Hospital cochlear implant bungle will be offered compensation after a review found long-standing systemic problems with the program dating back over nearly two decades.

title.children: SA government to compensate families after review into cochlear implant bungle reveals systemic problems

image.altText: Photo illustration of tree-lined Waterloo South street ahead of a state government development, housing tower in the background

items.synopsis: The redevelopment plans in Sydney's Waterloo Estate will now see nearly 500 extra social and affordable homes to address a "huge backlog".

title.children: Controversial redevelopment to unlock hundreds of social and affordable homes near Sydney CBD

image.altText: A fire burns over a hill. It is night,  and the sky is black with the fire and smoke red and orange.

items.synopsis: A parks and wildlife director says a planned fire that got through containment lines to encroach on Alice Springs was fuelled by an introduced species of grass that is in the region "to stay".

title.children: 'Not ideal' as nearly half of outback national park goes up in flames

image.altText: Bernardo Arevalo Guatemala Election

items.synopsis: Preliminary results show Bernardo Arevalo has been elected Guatemalan president — a victory many voters hope will reverse widespread allegations of corruption and the authoritarianism of previous administrations.

title.children: Anti-corruption crusader wins Guatemala presidency by landslide

image.altText: Woman in mask shopping in Woolworths packaged food aisle June 28

items.synopsis: Every day the impact of the cost-of-living crisis means we are paying more for most things. So what is the cost of living and how is it measured?

title.children: You don't have to be an economist to know Australia is in a cost-of-living crisis. But what can be done?

image.altText: Mon Lulan looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Men's sheds have become important community spaces, but for some women who want to learn practical home maintenance skills, it is not an environment they feel comfortable in.

title.children: 'Work with the men's shed': Mon faces challenges with trying to set up a 'she shed'

image.altText: Damaged theatre

items.synopsis: New pictures have emerged revealing the devastation caused by a Russian missile strike on the historic Ukrainian city of Chernihiv.

title.children: Pictures show aftermath of Russian missile strike on historic Ukrainian city

image.altText: An office building with the AGL logo showing, with a backdrop of other sky-high office buildings on a grey day.

items.synopsis: Westpac and BlueScope post their earnings at the start of another reporting-season week, AGL is set to keep Loy Yang open until mid-2035, and Qantas is hit with a class action. Follow live.

title.children: AGL to keep Loy Yang power station operational until 2035, Qantas hit with class action, ASX slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Agribusiness heavyweight Elders has downgraded its earnings guidance for the financial year, and expects its underlying earnings before interest and tax to be in the range of $ 165-175 million. Elders previously had been forecasting a guidance range of $180-200 million. The company says the reason for the downgrade comes down to: lower than forecast rural product sales in recent weeks greater than forecast pressure on rural product gross margin, especially with crop protection products further weakness in cattle and sheep prices Elders also notes "cautious customer sentiment" in some farming regions due to uncertain weather. "This uncertainty is now supported by the Bureau of Meteorology's long-range forecast for September to November which predicts a heightened probability of warmer and drier than average conditions in Eastern and Western parts of Australia and risk of an El Nino declaration," the statement to the ASX read. Elders also expects some variables will influence their financial outcomes ahead of September 30, including: Commodity prices Changes in value and volume of internationally traded livestock and fibre Unexpected and unforecast changes to seasons and severe weather events Potentia l supply chain disruptions, including geopolitical events General outlook and prosperity of the Australian farming sector
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Elders downgrades earnings guidance over 'cautious' sentiment with 'uncertain' weather

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China has cut its one-year benchmark lending rate as expected a little earlier today, but left its 5-year rate on hold. The one-year loan prime rate was reduced by 0.1 percentage points to 3.45% — down from 3.55% previously, while the 5-year rate remains at 4.2%. The reduction to lending rates comes as Chinese authorities try to stimulate demand for credit, with the world's second-largest economy faltering due to a worsening property slump, weak consumer spending and falling credit growth — all of which encouraged more policy stimulus. Most analysts had predicted a cut to both rates, which China had done in June to boost the economy. In China, most new and outstanding loans are based on the one-year loan prime rate, while the 5-year rate influences mortgage prices. The cut to the one-year rate followed the People's Bank of China unexpectedly lowering its medium-term policy rate last week, which is broadly considered a determinant to the future changes of other economic benchmarks. The decision in China has also caused Asian markets to stumble slightly, as investors are hoping there will be a repeat of substantial fiscal spending that has bolstered its economy in the past.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chinese banks trim lending rates to boost demand for credit as economy slumps

children.content: China has cut its one-year benchmark lending rate as expected a little earlier today, but left its 5-year rate on hold.
The

property slump

Most analysts had predicted a cut to both rates, which China had done in June to boost the economy.

The cut to the one-year rate followed the
People's Bank of China unexpectedly lowering its medium-term policy rate last week
, which is broadly considered a determinant to the future changes of other economic benchmarks.
The decision in China has also caused Asian markets to stumble slightly, as investors are hoping there will be a repeat of substantial fiscal spending that has bolstered its economy in the past.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we brought you the news of a class action being lodged against Qantas by Echo Law. Now the airline has commented on the proceedings. Echo Law alleges Qantas's failure to refund money when flights were cancelled, in accordance with its own conditions of carriage, was unlawful during the COVID-19 pandemic. But in a statement from a Qantas spokesperson, the airline rejects the claims put forward in the proceedings, and says it had not been served a claim as of midday (AEST) today. Here's the full statement from the airline: "We completely reject these claims. "We have already processed well in excess of $1 billion in refunds from COVID credits for customers who were impacted by lockdowns and border closures. "The majority of customers with COVID credits can get a refund and we've been running full page ads and sending emails to encourage customers who want a refund to contact us directly. "Qantas has one of the most flexible COVID credit policies of any airline, including among our global peers, and we've extended the expiry dates three times. "We've made a number of improvements to our systems along the way, including simplifying the process for a refund and making the credits easier to use, and that's clear from the amount of credit that has already been claimed." Qantas additionally notes that there was about $400 million in COVID credits remaining for Australian customers as at June 2023, ranging between $100 and $500, with a "large number of bookings" made through travel agents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We completely reject these claims': Qantas responds to class action

failure to refund money
when flights were cancelled, in accordance with its own conditions of carriage, was
unlawful
during the COVID-19 pandemic.
But in a statement from a Qantas spokesperson, the airline rejects the claims put forward in the proceedings, and says it had
not been served a claim as of midday (AEST) today
Here's the full statement from the airline:
"We
completely reject these claims
"We have already processed
well in excess of $1 billion in refunds from COVID credits
for customers who were impacted by lockdowns and border closures.
"The majority of customers with COVID credits can get a refund and we've been running full page ads and sending emails to encourage customers who want a refund to contact us directly.
"Qantas has one of the most flexible COVID credit policies of any airline, including among our global peers, and we've extended the expiry dates three times.
"We've made a number of improvements to our systems along the way,
including simplifying the process for a refund and making the credits easier to use
, and that's clear from the amount of credit that has already been claimed."
Qantas additionally notes that there was about
$400 million in COVID credits remaining for Australian customers
as at June 2023, ranging
between $100 and $500
, with a "large number of bookings" made through travel agents.

image.altText: A family of four with cows behind them.

items.synopsis: With neighbouring farms folding on Queensland's Scenic Rim, Kay and Dave Tommerup had to choose between closing or saving their fifth-generation dairy by radically changing how they did business.

title.children: Since cutting ties with its processor this dairy farm now makes four times as much

image.altText: Meditation session on a grassy clearing in bushland.

items.synopsis: A festival company which ran events promoted as "empowering women" is being pursued by workers who say they have not been paid and attendees who say the three-day "The Gathering of The Goddesses" was far from what was advertised.

title.children: 'Gathering of the Goddesses' event organiser being pursued by disgruntled patrons, artists

image.altText: Bella Ainsworth and Mitch Barrett with their three-month-old son, Saf, sit at a cafe in Shepparton.

items.synopsis: Bella Ainsworth and Mitch Barrett had just welcomed their first son, Saf, into the world before a heartbreaking terminal cancer diagnosis turned their lives upside down, with the community rallying to help support them.

title.children: With a child under a year old, cancer diagnosis has young family in fight of their lives

image.altText: man in yellow shirt and backpack

items.synopsis: Adil Abbas is the second food delivery worker to die in Sydney in the past month, prompting calls for reform of NSW's road rules.

title.children: 'We have to bury his dreams': Family mourn 19yo student killed while delivering food in Sydney

image.altText: The black silhouette of a church dome against a red sky and mountains in flames

items.synopsis: The fire has been raging out of control for the past five days, forcing the evacuation of more than 12,000 people on the Spanish island.

title.children: Tenerife wildfire was started deliberately, authorities say

image.altText: An Indigenous woman with long hair, looking sombre.

items.synopsis: Indigenous supporters of the Voice to Parliament have expressed dismay at WA Liberal leader Libby Mettam's change of heart.

title.children: 'We are so despised': Why a potential Voice defeat makes this woman 'feel like leaving the country'

image.altText: HMAS Canberra, off Tasmanian north coast as part of Exercise Ocean Explorer, March 2018.

items.synopsis: Three aircraft and helicopter carriers will sail together in a show of force coming shortly after Chinese coast guard ships used water cannons against Philippine vessels in the contested waterway, where disputes have long been regarded as a potential flashpoint.

title.children: Australia, US and Japan plan joint navy drills in disputed South China Sea

image.altText: England goalkeeper Mary Earps shouts at Spain's Jenni Hermoso after saving a penalty in the Women's World Cup final.

items.synopsis: One of England's best makes a costly blunder, Spain's captain shows off a hidden message and La Roja give the Lionesses a bit of love after the match. Here are five things you might have missed in the Women's World Cup final.

title.children: Five quick hits — Spain's classy gesture and what was scribbled on that shirt in the World Cup final
